docs.lead_paragraph: It has been nearly a month since the Institute of Medicine released its report on Agent Orange exposure and so-called Blue Water Navy veterans from Vietnam, yet the Department of Veterans Affairs says it is still reviewing the document. That’s not surprising, for the report is chock-full of nonconclusions, unknowns and uncertainties.

headline.main: Inconclusive Agent Orange Study Is Conclusive Enough for Vet Groups

docs.abstract: Advocates for Vietnam Navy veterans say a recent report bolsters their case for benefits for Agent Orange-linked diseases.
docs.snippet: Advocates for Vietnam Navy veterans say a recent report bolsters their case for benefits for Agent Orange-linked diseases.

docs.lead_paragraph: RAHAL--James J. Rahal M.D. James J. Rahal, M.D. The world of medicine, and the world, lost a giant this weekend as Dr. James Rahal passed away. His many colleagues at New York Hospital Queens join, in deep sadness, his beloved family - his wife Barbara Britton, his children James, Susan and Linda as well as his grandchildren Karyn, Carly and Christine, to mourn his death. We also celebrate his successes on the frontlines of the battle against some of the most challenging diseases of our time. Jim, as we all knew him, had a distinguished and productive career that spanned more than four decades. He dedicated his professional life to being a physician, scientist and professor in infectious disease and infection control. He achieved his undergraduate degree from Harvard-cum laude; and earned his medical degree from Tufts University-cum laude in 1959. He came to New York Hospital Queens as Director of Infectious Disease in 1988, and beyond the enormous contributions he made to the medical center's patients and his colleagues, he shaped the Infectious Disease specialists of the future as a clinical professor of medicine for Weill Medical College of Cornell University. In the 1980s and 1990s, he was recognized internationally as the scientific leader who discovered, and then published, his findings on the resistance of bacteria to antibiotics. He was among the first to participate in trials with the then â€œnewâ€ cephalosporins. His work on multi-drug resistant gram negative bacilli has led the field and is often quoted. When HIV/AIDS emerged as a growing public health issue, he became actively involved in addressing innovative drug therapies, patient access to treatment and public policy decisions. Most significantly, he served as a member of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) Data Safety Monitoring Board - a small group of multidisciplinary specialists, who determined the safety of national studies for HIV/AIDS. In 1999, he was one of the first physicians in the U.S. to recognize the outbreak pattern of the West Nile virus when it began infecting patients in Queens. He became one of the nation's foremost experts on the West Nile virus. He developed the first FDA-approved treatment for the West Nile virus in 2002, and he created a national, multi-site research protocol to determine the results of the Interferon alpha-2b for treatment of the virus. This unique protocol was patented in 2005. On a personal level, Dr. Rahal was recognized for his self-effacing and gracious manner. He was a consummate teacher and as a result, he received countless awards for teaching and research--including the Albion Bernstein MD Award in 2004 by the Medical Society of the State of New York. His work has been published in numerous prestigious journals, such as the New England Journal of Medicine, JAMA and Science magazine. The news media often sought his expertise on antibiotic resistance, the West Nile virus and infectious diseases. His studies, including those developed for the NIH, have affected many lives and have served to raise the bar of excellence in medicine and science for future generations. Services include Two Memorial Visitation Services: Thursday, June 16, 7:00- 9:00pm at Barrett's Funeral Home 424 West 51st Street, NY NY, Friday, June 17, 7:00- 9:00pm at Barrett's Funeral Home 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ www.BarrettFuneralHome.net A Memorial Church Service will be held Saturday, June 18 at 10:00am at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 4 Woodland Road, Montvale, NJ (201-391-3181) www.saintpaulsmontvale.org. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to either of the following: Laboratory for Infectious Disease Research c/o BMA Foundation, New York Hospital Queens, http://www.nyhq.org/Ways_to_Give or 56-45 Main Street, Flushing NY 11355 Histiocytosis Foundation www.histio.org or 1-800-548-2758. On behalf of his family, our trustees, administration, employees and medical staff, as well as the dedicated physicians and staff of the Infectious Disease Division, we say goodbye to a wonderful husband, father and grandfather, an amazing physician, an unflagging scientist, a loyal teacher and mentor, and our beloved colleague. George F. Heinrich, M.D. – Chairman, Board of Trustees, Stephen S. Mills – President & Chief Executive Officer, John E. Sciortino – Senior Vice President & Chief Operating Officer, Stephen Rimar, M.D. – Senior Vice President & Chief Medical Officer, William G. Wolff, M.D. – Chairman, Medical Board, Jack M. Mann, M.D. – President, Medical Staff Society, David N. Rose, M.D. – Chairman, Department of Medicine, Mary Godfrey, RN – Vice President, Professional Services, Sorana Segal-Maurer, M.D.- Acting Chief, Infectious Disease, Carl Urban, Ph.D., Director, Laboratory for Infectious Disease Research, Wehbeh Wehbeh, M.D., Attending Physician David Rubin, M.D., Attending Physician

docs.lead_paragraph: Millions of dental patients who have successfully avoided unpleasant drill-and-fill procedures owe much to Dr. Irwin D. Mandel -- an expert on dental chemistry jocularly known among colleagues as a leader of ''the Salivation Army.'' Dr. Mandel, a founder of the preventive dentistry movement who did research into the biochemistry of saliva that has had significant impact in medical fields beyond his own, died on May 26 in Montclair, N.J., his daughter Carol Ann Mandel said. He was 89 and lived in West Caldwell, N.J.

headline.main: Dr. Irwin D. Mandel, 89, Dental Chemistry Expert

docs.abstract: Dr Irwin D Mandel, dental chemistry expert, dies at age 89; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: There are many tests for heart disease, the leading cause of death in the United States, and some of them are costly and potentially risky.

headline.seo: Some Heart Disease Screens May Be Unnecessary
headline.main: Some Heart Disease Screens May Be Unnecessary
headline.print_headline: Some Heart Disease Screens May Be Unnecessary

docs.snippet: There are many tests for heart disease, the leading cause of death in the United States, and some of them are costly and potentially risky.

docs.lead_paragraph: HEART disease remains the No. 1 cause of death in the United States, killing more than 800,000 people each year, and accounting for one in three of all deaths. It is no wonder, then, that screening for heart disease is a routine part of just about every physical exam given in this country. The number of these tests has increased significantly over the last 20 to 30 years, and these days screening may involve any of a dozen procedures -- some as simple as taking a patient's blood pressure, some as complicated as CT angiography, an expensive, controversial test that may carry health risks.

headline.main: Some Heart Disease Screens May Be Unnecessary
